title: How many seats will the Liberal Democratic Party win in the upcoming election for Japan's House of Representatives?
preds: I think the consensus is overestimating LDP chances. Nikkei's latest poll suggests they may substantially lose ground: https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/Japan-s-election/Abe-s-coalition-seen-near-supermajority-in-Japan-election-poll

Latest polls show LDP headed towards 280 to 300 seats. LDP held 288 seats in the last session. I do not think it is likely they will lose seats at this point. https://www.voanews.com/a/japan-pm-confident-ahead-sundays-election/4079406.html

A weak and split opposition will likely give LDP a comfortable majority https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-19/abe-set-for-landslide-win-in-japan-election-as-opponents-bicker, https://www.cfr.org/blog/japans-election-sunday

Polls from Japanese news sources report that the LDP will gain 20 or more seats putting the LDP at about 300 seats in the lower house.
https://rsf.org/en/japan. I am very skeptical that any forecasting by Japanese new sources offer a realistic forecast. I also am skeptical of the fact that over half of Japanese are undecided. Despite an uptick in popularity of Abe due to his response to the North Korean missile launches, I don't think that North Korea could launch enough missiles to mitigate the damage of his scandal laden administration and recent Regional elections.
    More accurate indications of a potential loss of seats for the LDP would be the recent bellwether election in Tokyo which saw an historic loss for the scandalized leader, Abe, of the LDP losing in an historic defeat to Koike her allies and her Tomin First no Kai regional party.
   This does not bode well for the LDP as Keiko formed a national party, Kibo no To, drawing from the DP, LDP and gaining support from Komeito. 
  Ideologically Keiko is just as terrifying as Abe
and embraces the Japanese nationalism of Nippon Kaigi that has allowed the LDP to become popular and form a governing coalition.  Additionally  Keiko was a former minister of Defense of the fourth most power military in the world (yes, Japan) supports amending the constitution to support  (I gotta say the f word) fascism and wants to turn Tokyo into Anime Land! She's got it all.

If the turnout rate hits a new record low, that would probably mean the ruling bloc maintains a two-thirds majority" said Hidenori Suezawa, financial and fiscal analyst at SMBC Nikko Securities. That is significant as Abe's conservative LDP needs a two-third majority in both houses of parliament in order to propose changes to the country's constitution. "On the other hand, if the turnout rate rises to the 60-per cent level, new (opposition) parties may make a leap forward," he said.
http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/japan-braces-for-election-day-typhoon

The relative collapse of the Party of Hope, and the stance of the NKP on the issues of national security take away votes from the two leading opposition parties. And although the CDP is expected to grow by 300%, the relative recentness, combined with the Japanese culture  of conformity won't draw as many votes as projected. The demographics, (~60% young to middle age and ~27% 65+) hint at a strong desire to retain the status quo.

According to the polling described in the link below, the LDP looks on track to win 289-300 seats. They currently hold 290 and I expect them to hold to around that range or a bit lower, in no small part due to the fading of the Party of Hope and other opposition parties.  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-12/polls-show-abe-may-keep-two-thirds-majority-in-japan-s-election

The polls hold consistently good news for the LDP, and 300-ish looks like the sweet spot. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-16/ldp-heading-to-best-japan-election-result-since-1986-poll-shows https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2017/10/d7ff9cbeb548-ldp-eyes-firm-victory-koike-party-fights-for-2nd-place-kyodo-poll.html http://m.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/2115605/polls-show-japan-pm-abe-set-landslide-win-support-tokyo-governor
Starting conservative around their current 288 as I dig deeper.
I’m assuming that Japan’s “Lower House” equates to our “House of Representatives”. See: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_Democratic_Party_(Japan)
